question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, has been mentioned as a potential candidate for the Republican nomination for the 2024 Presidential Election. However, as of now, he has not formally declared his candidacy, and several other prominent Republican figures are also in the running, including former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. The dynamics of the Republican primary can be unpredictable, and the selection of the nominee will depend on various factors, including campaign performance, voter sentiment, and delegate support. Given that Youngkin has not yet established a strong national presence compared to other candidates, and considering the competitive nature of the Republican primaries, the probability of him being the nominee appears to be relatively low. Therefore, while it is possible for him to be nominated, it seems unlikely based on the current landscape.

question.title: Given Larry Elder is the Republican nominee, will Glenn Youngkin also be the nominee?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Then, is Glenn Youngkin also selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

Resolution criteria: The question resolves as YES if Glenn Youngkin is indeed selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, despite Larry Elder also being selected. It resolves as NO if Glenn Youngkin is not selected. Note that this scenario is logically inconsistent under typical single-nominee conditions.

metadata.chain_of_thought: In a typical political context, especially within the framework of the Republican National Convention, there is usually only one nominee selected for the presidential election. The question posits a scenario where Larry Elder is already selected as the nominee. Under standard party rules and practices, it is logically inconsistent for another candidate, such as Glenn Youngkin, to also be selected as the nominee at the same time. Therefore, the likelihood of both being nominated is extremely low. Given that the question specifically asks if Glenn Youngkin will also be the nominee when Larry Elder is already selected, the answer must be NO. Hence, the probability of the question resolving YES is very small.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Joe Biden's decision to run for re-election in 2024 is influenced by various factors, including his approval ratings, the political landscape, and his own health and age. As of now, there are indications that he may lean towards running for a second term, despite some public doubts about his viability as a candidate. Historically, incumbents often seek re-election unless there are significant reasons not to. Given the time frame leading up to July 15, 2024, it seems unlikely that Biden would make a definitive announcement to withdraw from the race unless there are compelling reasons, such as health issues or overwhelming pressure from the party. question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of Kamala Harris's odds of winning increasing over the next week according to Nate Silver's model, we need to consider several factors. First, Nate Silver's model is based on a combination of polling data, historical trends, and statistical analysis. The current political climate, including any recent developments in the Democratic primaries, public opinion shifts, and media coverage, will significantly influence these odds.

As of the current date, if Harris's probability is below 46.6%, it would require a notable shift in public sentiment or polling data to push her odds above that threshold within a week. Given that political dynamics can be volatile, it's possible that events such as debates, campaign announcements, or major news stories could positively impact her standing.

However, without specific polling data or trends indicating a significant upward movement for Harris, it is difficult to assign a high probability to her achieving a >46.6% chance in such a short time frame. If current data suggests she is around 45% or lower, the probability of her surpassing 46.6% within a week would be relatively low.

Considering these factors, I would estimate a moderate probability that her odds will increase but not enough to confidently predict that they will exceed the specified threshold.

question.title: Conditional on Kamala's odds of winning increasing over the next week, will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President?

Historically, incumbents who face strong challengers from within their party may be influenced by the dynamics of the race, especially if they perceive that their chances of winning the nomination are dwindling.

However, Biden has shown a commitment to running for re-election, and unless there are overwhelming reasons—such as a significant drop in public support or health issues—he may not announce that he will not accept the nomination. Additionally, political announcements of this nature are often timed strategically, and Biden may choose to wait until closer to the deadline or until he perceives a clear need to step aside.

Considering these factors, while there is a possibility that Biden could announce he will not seek the nomination if Harris's odds increase dramatically, it is not a certainty. Therefore, the probability that Biden will announce he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024, remains relatively low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The question revolves around the potential application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. The political landscape surrounding Donald Trump is highly polarized, and while there have been discussions and legal opinions regarding the applicability of this section to him, there are significant barriers to actual enforcement. First, the interpretation and application of the 14th Amendment in this context would likely involve extensive legal challenges, and any attempt to block Trump from the ballot would be met with substantial opposition. Courts could be reluctant to apply such a measure, given the political implications and the precedent it could set. Additionally, the decision would vary by state, and not all states may choose to act on this basis, even if some might attempt it. Moreover, as of now, there are no definitive legal rulings that have established that Trump will be blocked from the ballot under these grounds. The political and legal environment is dynamic, but as of the resolution date, there is a considerable amount of uncertainty regarding the actual implementation of such a disqualification. Given these factors, while there is a possibility of Trump being challenged under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, the likelihood that he will be officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot in any U.S. state by the specified date seems low.

question.title: Given Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will he be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. 

Then, will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?

Resolution criteria:
- For the condition: Donald Trump must be selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee.
- For the outcome: Resolves "Yes" if, on July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports.
- The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. The question does not consider legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals after this date.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question revolves around the potential application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to Donald Trump if he is the Republican nominee for the 2024 Presidential Election. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment disqualifies individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States or given aid to its enemies. The interpretation and enforcement of this section are highly contentious and would likely involve significant legal battles, political maneuvering, and decisions by state officials and courts.

While there are ongoing debates about whether Trump's actions related to the January 6th Capitol riot could be classified as insurrection, it is uncertain whether any state would take the step to officially remove him from the ballot. Historically, the application of such constitutional provisions has been rare and often met with substantial resistance. Moreover, the political implications of removing a leading candidate from the ballot could deter state officials from pursuing such actions, especially in Republican-dominated states.

Given these factors, while there is a possibility that some states might attempt to block Trump from the ballot under Section 3, the likelihood of this happening and being officially confirmed by July 15, 2024, seems low. Therefore, I assess that the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot under these conditions is small.

question.body:

Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Section 3 of the 14th Amendment prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding office. The application of this provision to Donald Trump would depend on the legal interpretations surrounding his actions related to the January 6th Capitol riot and whether he is deemed to have engaged in insurrection. If Trump is not the Republican nominee for the 2024 election, it is still possible for him to appear on primary ballots unless specific legal actions are taken to block him based on Section 3. As of now, there have been various legal challenges regarding this issue, but no definitive ruling has been made that would universally remove him from the ballot. Furthermore, the political climate leading up to July 15, 2024, will likely influence whether any states take action to block him. Given the complexities of legal proceedings, potential appeals, and the political ramifications, it is uncertain whether he would be officially removed or blocked from the primary ballots by that date. Thus, while there is a possibility that he could be blocked under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, the lack of definitive legal action as of now makes it unlikely that he will be removed or blocked from the primary ballot across any U.S. state by July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

The question of whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot in any U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment involves a complex interplay of legal and political factors. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment was originally designed to prevent individuals who engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding office. The application of this section to Trump is highly contentious and would likely involve extensive legal battles.

As of now, there is no definitive legal ruling that indicates Trump will be removed from the ballot, and the political landscape is highly polarized. While some states may attempt to block him, the likelihood of achieving this on a wide scale is uncertain. Legal challenges would likely arise, and any decision to remove him would likely be appealed, making it difficult to secure a definitive ruling by the specified date of July 15, 2024.

Moreover, the political ramifications and the potential for public backlash against such actions could deter state officials from pursuing removal. The combination of these factors leads me to believe that while there may be attempts to block Trump from the ballot, the probability that he will actually be removed or blocked in a way that meets the criteria outlined in the question is relatively low.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context provided indicates that there is significant dissent among House Democrats regarding the plan to expedite President Biden's nomination. The involvement of Rep. Jared Huffman and the circulation of a drafted letter suggest that there is an organized effort to mobilize opposition. Given that the letter has already been drafted and is being circulated, it is reasonable to assume that there will be sufficient support from other Democrats who share similar concerns about the nomination process. The fact that multiple letters could also count towards the 20 signatures means that even if one letter does not achieve the threshold, others may. Given the current political climate, where party unity is often challenged and individual lawmakers are willing to voice their dissent, it seems likely that at least 20 Democrats will sign a letter opposing the early nomination plan.

1. It is possible that the countries winning gold medals are not the same as those winning other types of medals (silver or bronze). Therefore, it's feasible that countries could win their first-ever medals (but not gold) in other categories.
2. The Olympics usually feature a wide range of sports, and it is common for countries to achieve their first medals in different events, which may not be gold.
3. Historical data from previous Olympics shows that many countries have won medals without having previously secured gold.

Given these considerations, it is plausible that at least 5 countries could win their first Olympic medal even if fewer than 5 countries win their first Olympic gold medal.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

The qualification process involves performing well in the Semi-final, which is determined by a combination of jury voting and public voting. If Latvia presents a strong entry that resonates with both the jury and the public, their chances of qualifying increase significantly. However, the competition is fierce, with many countries vying for a limited number of spots in the Grand Final. Given this context, while there is potential for Latvia to qualify, the uncertainty surrounding their entry and the competitive nature of Eurovision suggests that it is not a certainty. Considering these factors, I estimate that the probability of Latvia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024 is moderate, reflecting both their potential and the inherent uncertainties of the competition.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

Given the popularity of the "Deadpool" franchise, the star power of Ryan Reynolds, and the anticipation surrounding this crossover, it seems quite plausible that the movie will indeed surpass the previous record. question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question revolves around the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. Given the current political landscape, there are ongoing discussions and legal challenges regarding Trump's eligibility due to his actions surrounding the January 6th insurrection. However, as of now, there has been no definitive legal ruling that has removed him from any ballot under this provision, and courts have historically been cautious about disqualifying candidates, especially in the context of elections.  

While there is a possibility that some states may attempt to block him from the ballot based on Section 3, the likelihood of this being fully realized and confirmed by the state government or courts by July 15, 2024, appears low. The legal landscape is complex, and it is likely that any attempts to disqualify him would lead to extensive legal battles, which could result in delays or reversals. Furthermore, the political implications of removing a high-profile candidate like Trump from the ballot would also create significant pushback from his supporters and could influence the decisions of state officials.  

Given these factors, while it is not impossible for Trump to be removed from the ballot, the probability of this happening in a way that meets the criteria set out in the question by the specified date is relatively low.

question.title: If Joe Biden announces he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024, will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden announces before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The announcement must be definitive, public, official, unambiguous, and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination.

Then, is it true that Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3? This is based on the 538 national polling average for the 2024 presidential election as reported on the chart for July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Joe Biden were to announce that he will not seek the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024, it would create a significant shift in the political landscape. Such a definitive announcement would likely lead to increased support for Donald Trump, as Biden's absence would eliminate a major competitor for the presidency. The polling dynamics would change, and Trump's lead over Biden could be expected to widen. Given the context of the 2024 election and the typical behavior of polling in response to major announcements, it is plausible that Trump's lead could indeed be greater than 2 but less than or equal to 3 points. However, the exact margin would depend on various factors, including the potential Democratic replacement candidate and voter sentiment at that time. Overall, while there is a reasonable likelihood that Trump's lead would fall within that range, there is also uncertainty, which prevents a very high probability estimate.

question.title: If Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination, will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden does not announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This means there is no definitive, public, official announcement from Biden or his campaign indicating that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination for another term as President in the 2024 cycle.

Given this scenario, will Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average? This question will resolve based on the value reported on 538's national polling average chart for the date of July 15, 2024, accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead. For example, a value of 2.4 means Trump is 2.4 points ahead of Biden.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the likelihood of Donald Trump having a lead over Joe Biden that is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 points on July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors. First, if Joe Biden does not announce that he will not accept the nomination by this date, it might suggest he is still in contention, which could influence voter sentiment positively for him. However, the current political climate, including economic factors, public opinion, and Trump's overall popularity, will also play significant roles in shaping polling numbers.

Polling averages can fluctuate significantly in the lead-up to an election, and while Biden's lack of an announcement might keep him in the race, it could also lead to increased uncertainty among voters. If Trump maintains a strong base and is able to capitalize on any weaknesses in Biden's campaign, it is plausible that his lead could fall within the specified range. Historical trends show that incumbents often experience challenges, and given the polarized nature of current U.S. politics, a narrow lead for Trump is feasible.

Considering these dynamics, I would estimate that there is a moderate probability that Trump's lead will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 points on the specified date.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Liz Cheney has positioned herself as a prominent figure within the Republican Party, especially due to her stance against former President Donald Trump and her advocacy for traditional conservative values. However, as of now, she is not leading in polls or support among Republican voters, and the party appears to be coalescing around other candidates who are more aligned with the current base. Additionally, the Republican National Convention often favors candidates who have strong grassroots support and are aligned with the party's primary voter base, which currently does not seem to favor Cheney. Given these dynamics, the likelihood of her being selected as the nominee appears low. Therefore, I estimate that the probability of Liz Cheney being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election is quite small.

question.body:

If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

Then, will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question hinges on two significant events: the Republican Party losing Ohio's 6th congressional district in a special election and Liz Cheney's subsequent nomination as the Republican candidate for the 2024 Presidential Election. Losing a congressional district, especially one that has been held by the party, could indicate broader electoral challenges for the Republicans, potentially shifting the party dynamics. However, Liz Cheney's chances of becoming the nominee are influenced by multiple factors beyond just this one election outcome, including her standing within the party, the support from party leadership, and the overall political landscape leading up to the convention.

Moreover, the Republican National Convention will feature many candidates, and the dynamics can change rapidly based on primary results, endorsements, and the political climate in the lead-up to the convention. Given these factors, while losing a congressional seat could complicate Cheney's path, it does not definitively eliminate her chances of becoming the nominee.

Considering all these aspects, I estimate that the probability of Liz Cheney being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, given the Republican Party loses Ohio's 6th congressional district, is relatively low but not impossible.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, Joe Biden has not made any definitive public statements indicating that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in 2024. Historically, incumbent presidents often seek re-election unless there are significant political, health, or personal reasons that lead them to step back. Given Biden's position as the incumbent and the lack of any major health issues that have been publicly acknowledged, it seems more likely that he would pursue re-election rather than announce a withdrawal. Additionally, the political landscape can change, but as it stands, the probability of him making such an announcement before the specified date appears low. Therefore, I would estimate the probability of him announcing that he will not accept the nomination as low.

question.title: Given a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: A member of the Trump family, such as Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump, is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. Given this scenario, will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolution criteria for the condition (P): Resolves Yes if one of the specified members of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024.

Resolution criteria for the outcome (Q): Resolves Yes if before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive. If not made by the deadline, resolves No.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question revolves around whether Joe Biden will publicly announce that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, under the condition that a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee. Several factors need to be considered:

1. **Current Political Climate**: As of now, Joe Biden is the incumbent President and has indicated intentions to run for re-election. There is significant pressure for incumbents to seek re-election, especially if they have not faced major controversies or health issues.

2. **Trump Family Nominee Impact**: If a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee, it may heighten the stakes of the election. Biden may feel compelled to run against a high-profile opponent, as the Trump family has significant political influence and a strong base of support.

3. **Public Statements**: Biden's public statements and campaign strategies leading up to the deadline will be crucial. If he remains silent or indicates a desire to run, it is less likely he will formally withdraw. 

4. **Historical Precedents**: Historically, incumbents do not typically withdraw from running unless there are compelling reasons, such as health issues or significant political pressure. 

5. **Timing of Announcement**: The timing of any announcement is critical. If Biden has not made any announcement by July 15, 2024, the question would resolve as "No." Given the timeline, it is plausible that he may wait until closer to the deadline to make a decision, especially if he believes he can win.

Considering these factors, it seems likely that Biden will not announce that he will not accept the nomination. Therefore, the probability of the question resolving YES is relatively low.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question hinges on two key factors: the status of the Republican nominee and Joe Biden's intentions regarding the Democratic nomination. Additionally, Biden's administration has faced challenges, but he may choose to stay in the race regardless of the Republican nominee. question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of FiveThirtyEight projecting Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024, we need to consider several factors. First, as of my last training cut-off in October 2023, Biden's approval ratings and polling numbers were showing variability, but he was generally seen as a competitive candidate against Trump. The political landscape can shift significantly due to various factors such as economic conditions, major events, or campaign developments leading up to the election.

Given that the election is still several months away, and assuming no major negative events occur for Biden, it is reasonable to expect that he may have a competitive edge or at least a strong footing against Trump. However, the dynamics of the race could still favor Trump depending on how the political climate evolves, including potential primary challenges, economic conditions, or public sentiment.

FiveThirtyEight's model is based on a combination of polling data and statistical simulations, which means that if Biden maintains a solid polling position, he could very well be projected as the favorite. However, if Trump regains momentum or if there are significant shifts in voter sentiment, it's possible that he could be favored instead.

Overall, while it is difficult to predict with certainty due to the fluid nature of politics, I would estimate that there is a reasonable likelihood that Biden will be projected as the favorite on that date, given the context and current trends.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris’ VP Pick be Kelly or Shapiro (YES), or neither of them (NO)?
question.body:
The two favorites for Kamala’s running mate are currently Mark Kelly and Josh Shapiro. It is reported, Kamala will choose before August 7th.

This market resolves YES if/when Kamala Harris announces her pick for running mate being either Mark Kelly or Josh Shapiro.

This market resolves NO if/when Kamala Harris announces anyone else being her running mate.

I will wait until the pick is confirmed by Kamala herself to resolve this.

comment if you have any questions or news 💙

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around Kamala Harris's choice for her vice-presidential running mate, with Mark Kelly and Josh Shapiro being the two leading candidates. Given the context that the decision will be made before August 7th, we can assess a few factors. 1. **Current Favoritism**: Both Kelly and Shapiro are currently seen as the favorites, which suggests a higher likelihood that one of them will be chosen. The market dynamics often reflect public sentiment and insider information, which can be indicative of the actual decision-making process. 2. **Political Landscape**: The political environment leading up to the election can influence the choice of running mate. If there is a strong push from party insiders or grassroots movements favoring either candidate, that could solidify their chances. 3. **Historical Precedents**: Typically, vice-presidential picks are made from within a certain pool of candidates who have been vetted and are seen as viable. Given that both Kelly and Shapiro are already prominent figures, it is less likely that an unexpected candidate outside of this pool will be chosen. 4. **Timeframe**: With the deadline for the announcement approaching, the decision-making process would likely be narrowing down to these two candidates. The closer we get to the announcement date, the more likely it is that the speculation around Kelly or Shapiro will materialize into a confirmed pick. Taking all these factors into account, it seems quite probable that Kamala Harris will choose either Mark Kelly or Josh Shapiro as her running mate, rather than someone else entirely.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Poland qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we must consider several factors. First, Poland has a history of participation in the Eurovision Song Contest and has qualified for the Grand Final in previous years, which suggests a reasonable chance of qualifying again. Additionally, the overall competitiveness of their entry (the artist and song) will play a significant role, and while we don't have specific information on the 2024 entry yet, Poland typically sends strong contenders. Furthermore, the voting system in Eurovision, which includes both jury and public votes, can favor countries with popular entries. Given the current trends in music and Poland's active engagement in the contest, I would estimate a moderate to high probability of qualification. However, it's important to note that there are uncertainties regarding the quality of the entry and the competitiveness of other countries in the semi-final. Taking all these factors into account, I would estimate a probability of around 0.65 that Poland will qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The men's 100m dash is one of the most prestigious events in athletics, and breaking the Olympic record of 9.63 seconds is a significant milestone that many elite sprinters aim for. The current world record is 9.58 seconds, set by Usain Bolt, and many athletes have been approaching this mark in recent years. The competition in sprinting has been intensifying, with several young, talented sprinters emerging who have the potential to challenge existing records. Additionally, factors such as advancements in training, technology, and nutrition may contribute to faster times. Given the historical context, the increasing competitiveness of the event, and the possibility of favorable conditions (such as weather and track surface), there is a reasonable chance that the Olympic record could be broken in 2024. However, it is still a challenging feat, and while the probability is not overwhelmingly high, it is significant enough to suggest that breaking the record is plausible.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question revolves around the political dynamics within the Democratic Party regarding President Biden's re-election campaign. Currently, there are indications from multiple sources that some Democratic members are expressing concerns about Biden's viability in the upcoming election. The reports of two safe-seat members publicly urging Biden to step down and two endangered Democrats writing off his chances suggest a growing sentiment against his candidacy. Additionally, the mention of letters circulating among House Democrats indicates organized efforts to push Biden to reconsider his campaign.

However, for the market to resolve YES, it requires a specific group of at least five named Democratic members to formally pressure Biden as a collective. While there are signs of dissent, the threshold of five individuals acting together in a unified message is significant. Given the political landscape, it is plausible that more members could join this effort, especially as the election approaches and pressure mounts. Nonetheless, the requirement for public identification and a coordinated effort adds a layer of complexity that might not be met.

Considering these factors, while there is a notable movement within the party, the actual organization of five named members to pressure Biden before the deadline is uncertain but possible. Therefore, I estimate a moderate probability that this will occur.

question.title: Given Georgia fails to qualify for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, will Czechia qualify?
question.body:
This conditional question explores the relationship between the qualification outcomes of Georgia and Czechia in Eurovision 2024.

Suppose the following is true: Georgia does not participate in a Semi-final or is not officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Then, will Czechia participate in a Semi-final and be officially announced by the EBU as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final?

Resolution criteria:
- The condition (Georgia failing to qualify) resolves as **Yes** if Georgia does not participate in a Semi-final or is not officially announced as having qualified for the Grand Final. For any other outcome, it resolves as **No**.
- The outcome (Czechia qualifying) resolves as **Yes** if Czechia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced as having qualified for the Grand Final. If Czechia does not qualify, it resolves as **No**.

If the condition is not met, the question resolves as N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question hinges on the relationship between Georgia's qualification status and Czechia's qualification status for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Georgia fails to qualify (either by not participating or not being announced as qualified), this condition must be met for the question to resolve as YES. However, the qualification of Czechia is independent of Georgia's status; it is possible for Czechia to qualify regardless of Georgia's outcome. The Eurovision qualification process involves multiple factors, including the performance in the Semi-finals, public voting, and jury votes, which can vary significantly from year to year. Without specific information about Czechia's entry and its potential to qualify, it is difficult to assert a strong likelihood that Czechia will qualify just based on Georgia's failure. Thus, while Georgia's failure creates a scenario where the condition for the question is satisfied, it does not inherently guarantee that Czechia will qualify. The independence of their outcomes leads me to assess that the probability is relatively low.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess whether Donald Trump will gain at least 3% more support among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden compared to a generic Democrat, we need to consider several factors. Firstly, polling data indicates that Trump tends to perform better against Biden than against generic Democrats, as evidenced by various public opinion polls showing Biden losing to Trump outside the margin of error. This suggests that voters may have a more negative perception of Biden compared to a generic Democrat, potentially increasing Trump's support.

Moreover, the specific nature of the Manifold respondents may also play a role in how accurately they reflect broader public sentiment. If they are indeed representative of the general public, the trend observed in broader polls could hold true in this context. However, if Manifold respondents differ significantly from the general population, it could skew the results.

Given these considerations, it seems plausible that Trump could gain at least 3% more support against Biden compared to a generic Democrat. While there are uncertainties regarding the representativeness of the Manifold respondents, the existing polling trends favor the likelihood of a significant gain for Trump in this scenario.

question.title: Will GUE/NGL hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if GUE/NGL holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The GUE/NGL (European United Left/Nordic Green Left) is a left-wing political group in the European Parliament. Historically, it has not been one of the largest groups, often trailing behind the center-right European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). Given the political landscape in Europe, the rise of right-wing and populist parties in recent years, as well as the potential for fragmentation of the left, it seems unlikely that GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 elections. Additionally, the electoral dynamics, including voter sentiment and coalition-building, suggest that larger parties will continue to dominate. Therefore, while it's possible for GUE/NGL to gain seats, the probability of them holding the most seats is low.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context provided indicates that there is already some movement among Democratic House Members and Senators regarding the possibility of urging President Biden to drop out of the 2024 presidential race. With reports of at least two members publicly expressing their concerns and multiple drafts of letters circulating, it suggests a growing sentiment among certain Democrats that could lead to organized pressure on Biden. While it is essential that at least five members act collectively and publicly to meet the criteria for a YES resolution, the existing discussions and actions indicate that this is plausible. Given the political climate, especially with a focus on electability and the upcoming elections, it seems likely that more members may join this effort as the deadline approaches. Therefore, the probability of at least five named Democratic members coming together to pressure Biden before July 20th appears to be relatively high.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The potential for at least 5 countries to win their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Paris Games is quite plausible. The Olympics often feature a diverse range of sports, and new countries frequently emerge as competitive in various disciplines. Recent trends show that smaller nations or those with developing sports programs are increasingly successful in achieving medals, often due to the introduction of new sports or changes in competition formats. The 2020 Tokyo Olympics saw several countries winning their first medals, indicating a growing trend. Given that the Paris Games will likely have similar dynamics, it is reasonable to expect that at least 5 countries could achieve this milestone. Therefore, I estimate a relatively high probability for this outcome.

question.title: Given at least 5 countries win their first Olympic medal, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body: Suppose the following is true: At least 5 countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris 2024 Olympics, according to credible sources. Then, will at least 5 countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris 2024 Olympics, according to credible sources? The question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the 2024 Olympics, and **No** otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Winning a first Olympic medal does not necessarily imply that a country will also win a first Olympic gold medal. The distinction is important because a country could win a silver or bronze medal without achieving gold. While the premise states that at least 5 countries will win their first Olympic medal, it does not guarantee that those countries will also win gold. Historically, many countries have won medals in their Olympic debuts without securing gold. Therefore, while it is possible that at least 5 countries could win their first gold medal, it is not certain given the information provided. The probability of at least 5 countries winning their debut gold medal is likely lower than the probability of them winning any medal at all.

question.title: Conditional on fewer than 5 countries winning their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Games, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Fewer than 5 countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, according to credible sources. Then, will at least 5 countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics? 

Resolution criteria for the condition: Resolves as YES if fewer than 5 countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics.
Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves as YES if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to credible sources. Resolves as NO otherwise.
If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question hinges on two key conditions: the number of countries winning their first Olympic medal and the number of countries winning their first Olympic gold medal. If fewer than 5 countries win their first-ever Olympic medal, it implies a limited participation or success from new countries in the Olympics. Given that winning a gold medal is a higher achievement than simply winning any medal, it stands to reason that if fewer than 5 countries are winning any medals, it is highly unlikely that 5 or more of them would also achieve gold medals. The relationship between the number of countries winning their first medal and those winning gold is likely to be directly correlated, suggesting that if the former is limited, so too will be the latter. Therefore, under the condition that fewer than 5 countries win their first-ever Olympic medal, the likelihood of at least 5 countries winning their debut gold medal is very low.

question.title: If Joe Biden drops out, will a reliable media outlet cover the story at least 6 hours in advance?
question.body:
Question resolves YES if a big and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers the dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before President Joe Biden officially announces his dropout via letter, speech, etc.

Local news, conspiracy websites, or comments by individual users on Manifold will not be sufficient.

This market will be resolved as N/A if President Joe Biden does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The likelihood of a reliable media outlet covering Joe Biden's potential dropout before it is officially announced hinges on several factors. Firstly, if Biden were to drop out, it would be a significant political event, likely drawing considerable attention from major news outlets. Given the current political climate and the heightened scrutiny on presidential candidates, it's reasonable to expect that reputable media would seek to confirm such news before it becomes official, especially considering that unofficial confirmations often circulate in political circles before formal announcements. Additionally, major news outlets have established protocols for reporting on significant political events, including the need for multiple sources to confirm information before publication. Given the importance of the story, it is plausible that insiders or campaign sources would leak information to journalists, allowing for coverage at least six hours in advance. However, the probability is not absolute, as it depends on various factors, including the timing of the announcement, the nature of the sources, and the media outlet's editorial policies. Nonetheless, the overall context suggests a high likelihood of coverage.

question.title: Will the Republicans Party of France (Les Républicains) form a political alliance with the National Rally for the 2024 French legislative election?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if before June 30, 2024, an electoral alliance or coalition agreement is officially announced between the Republicans Party (Les Républicains) and National Rally (Rassemblement National) for the upcoming [French legislative election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_French_legislative_election), according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).  If no such agreement is announced, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The political landscape in France is currently characterized by a significant polarization between traditional parties and the far-right National Rally. Historically, Les Républicains (the Republicans Party) have been hesitant to form alliances with the National Rally due to ideological differences and the potential backlash from their voter base. However, in recent years, there has been a noticeable shift in some traditional parties across Europe towards collaboration with far-right parties, especially in the context of electoral strategies aimed at maximizing seats in legislatures. Given the upcoming 2024 French legislative election, there may be pressure on Les Républicains to consider alliances to bolster their electoral chances, particularly in regions where they might struggle against leftist or centrist candidates. Nevertheless, the deep-rooted ideological divide and the potential risks of alienating moderate voters may still deter them from forming a formal alliance. Considering these factors, while there is a possibility of an alliance being formed, it remains relatively low due to the historical context, current political dynamics, and the potential risks involved. Therefore, I estimate the probability of an official alliance being announced by June 30, 2024, as moderate but leaning towards unlikely.

question.title: Given Joe Biden drops out and no reliable media outlet covers it 6 hours in advance, will Israel carry out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024?

Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden drops out and no big and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers the dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before President Joe Biden officially announces his dropout via letter, speech, etc.

Local news, conspiracy websites, or comments by individual users on Manifold will not be sufficient.

This market will be resolved as N/A if President Joe Biden does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention.

Then, is it true that Israel will carry out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024? This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question hinges on two major events: Joe Biden dropping out of the presidential race and Israel conducting a deadly attack within Iran. The first event, Biden's dropout, would be a significant political event, likely leading to various geopolitical reactions. However, the condition that no major media outlet covers this dropout in advance complicates the scenario, as it suggests a lack of public awareness or preparation for the fallout of such a decision.

Israel has a history of conducting military operations against perceived threats, particularly in Iran, due to its ongoing concerns regarding Iran's nuclear program and regional influence. However, the timing of such an attack would be influenced by numerous factors, including international relations, domestic politics within Israel, and the broader geopolitical landscape.

Given that the question specifies that the attack must occur before May 1, 2024, and considering the potential for increased tensions following a significant political shift in the U.S. (like Biden's dropout), there is a plausible scenario where Israel might act preemptively. However, the requirement that the attack must result in the death of at least five individuals adds another layer of uncertainty, as it is difficult to predict the outcomes of military actions.

Overall, while there is a possibility of an attack, the specific conditions and timing make it difficult to assign a high probability to the event occurring. Therefore, I estimate the probability of Israel carrying out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024, as moderate.

However, qualifying from the Semi-final can be competitive, as it depends on the quality of their entry and the performance relative to other countries. The overall strength of competitors, the appeal of the song, staging, and public voting dynamics also play crucial roles. Therefore, I estimate the probability of this question resolving as YES to be around 0.65.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine whether Trump will gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, we need to consider several factors. Historically, polls show that Trump often performs better against Biden than against other Democrats. This trend is supported by various polls indicating Biden's lower popularity compared to a generic Democrat. 

However, the Manifold respondents' representation of the general public is crucial. If they are indeed representative, the trend observed in broader polls would likely hold true. Given that Biden's approval ratings have fluctuated and considering the current political landscape, it is plausible that Trump could gain a notable percentage against Biden, potentially exceeding the 3% margin.

Additionally, the dynamics of voter sentiment towards Biden, especially in light of economic concerns and other pressing issues, could further influence the results. The likelihood of Trump outperforming his generic counterpart by at least 3% seems reasonable, especially given the historical context and current polling trends.

question.title: Will Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question of whether Donald Trump will testify at the hush money trial involves several factors. First, it's important to consider the legal context: Trump is facing serious charges related to the hush money payments, and his testimony could be critical for both the prosecution and defense. Historically, high-profile defendants in similar situations often choose to testify, as it allows them to present their side of the story directly to the jury. However, Trump’s legal team may advise him against testifying due to the potential risks involved, including the possibility of self-incrimination or the challenges of cross-examination. Furthermore, the political implications of his testimony may also weigh heavily on his decision, given his ongoing public profile and the polarized opinions surrounding him. As of the current date, there have been no definitive announcements regarding Trump’s intention to testify. However, the trial is still a few months away, and circumstances may change, including the emergence of new evidence or legal strategies that could influence his decision. Given the high stakes of the trial and the historical precedent for defendants in similar situations to testify, I assess that there is a reasonable probability that credible sources will report Trump testifying at the trial.

question.title: If Donald Trump testifies at the hush money trial, will he gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents against Joe Biden compared to a generic Democrat?
question.body:

Then, will Donald Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot compared to a generic Democrat? This resolves YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in the poll with Joe Biden exceeds that in the poll with a generic Democrat by 3% or more when both polls close on July 6. The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03. Otherwise, it is NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question revolves around the potential impact of Donald Trump testifying at the hush money trial on his polling numbers against Joe Biden compared to a generic Democrat. Historically, high-profile events such as trials can influence public perception and polling numbers, especially for polarizing figures like Trump. If he testifies, it could galvanize his base and potentially sway undecided voters who may view him as more transparent or courageous for facing the trial.

However, the extent of this impact can vary. Factors such as the prevailing political climate, media coverage, and the specific context of the trial will play significant roles. Polling data indicates that Trump has a strong base, but whether this translates to a 3% increase against Biden specifically is uncertain. 

Generic Democrat candidates often perform well against Trump, and the difference in polling could hinge on how voters perceive the trial and its implications. If the testimony is perceived negatively, it might not have the desired effect. Conversely, if it is framed positively or if it energizes his supporters, it could lead to an increase in his numbers.

Given the uncertainty surrounding the trial's impact and the competitive nature of the 2024 election, it is plausible that Trump could gain some percentage points, but a 3% increase is not guaranteed and depends on many variables. Therefore, while there is a possibility of an increase, the likelihood of it being at least 3% is moderate.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03. Otherwise, it is NO.
